Award.AwardTitle: Repair and regeneration of osteochondral defects in mouse articular joints

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1133883
Wei

In a high percentage of patients, damages to the articular cartilage surface and the underlying subchondral bone can easily progress to joint degeneration, especially osteoarthritis which is the main cause of chronic disability in US. Extensive efforts have been made in osteochondral defect treatment, but there is still no widely accepted method which produces consistent satisfactory results. The regenerated cartilage is inferior to the original cartilage morphologically, biochemically, and biomechanically. Instead of forming articular cartilage, fibrocartilage is normally generated, which lacks of the long-term stability and cannot withstand prolonged stress to the joint. Thus, there is a need for a new approach that outperforms currently used methods. In this study, we propose to develop a graded scaffold with structure and mechanical properties mimicking those of natural cartilage, load the scaffold with articular-specific chondroprogenitor cells identified by GFP reporters, and then implant the cell-loaded scaffold into a novel transgenic mouse cartilage model to test for osteochondral repair and regeneration. It is expected that an optimum cell-scaffold construct will be determined which effectively regenerates osteochondral cartilage with excellent functionality and long-term stability.

Intellectual merits: The novelty of the current proposal includes: (1) the development of a graded scaffold with structure, orientation, composition and mechanical properties mimicking those of natural cartilage and subchondral bone; (2) the development of an in-depth understanding of chondrocytes differentiation pathways and establishment of their lineage interrelationships; (3) the identification of articular-specific chondroprogenitor cells using a series of cartilage GFP reporters; (4) the development of an informative transgenic murine cartilage model to assess osteochondral repair and its integration with host tissues at a relatively low cost.

Broader impact: The proposed project has a broader impact on various scientific disciplines. The results of the proposed research will contribute to our understanding of the cell-scaffold interactions, chondrocyte differentiation pathways, and host/donor cell contribution to the articular cartilage restoration for the first time. The information gained here will be an essential ingredient in developing and interpreting tissue engineering strategies to determine the optimal scaffold design and source of progenitors, and whether a repair process is initiated from the host or donor. Distinguishing the completeness of the repair in terms of the composition of cells that fill the repair region will be another measure of success of a repair strategy. The proposed research will be transformative to the tissue engineering field as it directly addresses the existing problems of the osteochondral cartilage repair and its approach may provide an effect solution to these problems.

This project will result in the training of a graduate student and a number of undergraduate students in areas of tissue engineering, while exposing them to a multidisciplinary working environment. Efforts will be made to recruit female and minority students by integrating our research activities with existing recruiting efforts at the Department, the School and the University levels as well as participating in activities organized by various professional societies dedicated to underrepresented minorities. In addition, we will perform K-12 outreach to get high school students, especially female and underrepresented minorities, excited about engineering research. The results obtained from the project will be disseminated broadly via publishing in scientific journals, presenting in conferences and publicizing to general public via a website. We will make sure that all data will be kept for at least three years after conclusion of the award or three years after public release, whichever is later. We will also make our transgenic mice available to the tissue engineering community so that more researchers can use them to optimize their repair strategies.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Injury to the surface of an articular cartilage is a major problem, affecting more than 60% of patients at knee arthoscopy. Extensive efforts have been made in osteochondral defect treatment, but there is still no widely accepted method which produces consistent satisfactory results.  The regenerated cartilage is inferior to the original cartilage morphologically, biochemically, and biomechanically. Instead of forming articular cartilage, fibrocartilage is normally generated, which lacks of the long-term stability and cannot withstand prolonged stress to the joint. Thus, there is a need for a new approach that outperforms currently used methods. Researchers from the University of Connecticut have developed two types of novel biomaterial scaffolds that mimic the zonal orientation and composition of articular cartilage in a monolithic scaffold. This approach may provide an effective solution to current existing problems of articular cartilage repair.

Intellectual Merits: We have developed novel collagen scaffolds that mimic the orientation and composition of superficial, transition, and deep zones of articular cartilage seamlessly. This material design has been advanced through creating novel osteochondral monolithic scaffolds. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report of the development of a monolithic scaffold mimicking the zone-specific orientation and composition of the superficial, transition, calcified, and osseous regions of native osteochondral tissue.  These materials, in combination with loaded mesenchymal stem cells, may induce optimal regeneration of osteochondral tissue and represent a significant technological advancement in osteochondral indury treatment. Completion of this project will directly address the issues concerning articular cartilage and subchondral bone damage, and provide a new treatment option for joint damage that exceeds the limitations of currently available treatments. Scientifically, this project will address the impact of materials design on tissue regeneration in the context of osteochondral injury.

Broader Impacts: The proposed project has a broader impact on various scientific disciplines. The development of these novel materials may lead to better tissue regeneration than currently available treatments, reducing healthcare costs associated with osteochondral injury treatment and increasing the quality of life of patients suffering with these injuries. These new freeze casting methods may be used to guide the development of materials used in other fields including, but not limited to, energy storage, structural engineering, and filter development.

This project allows us to train four graduate students (two are female) and several undergraduate students in the field of biomaterials fabrication and tissue engineering. It also allows us to involve in the teaching of both fundamental and advanced materials science and biomedical engineering concepts to the students working on the project. Results from the study have been disseminated in scientific journals and presentations in professional conferences. 


Last Modified: 11/03/2016
Modified by: Mei Wei

Images (1 of )
  • Figure 1: Stitched FESEM longitudinal micrograph of 2% (wt/vol) collagen multi-zonal scaffold fabricated by sequential freeze casting (A). Higher magnification images of zone-specific collagen fiber alignment in SZ (B), TZ (C), and DZ (D).
    Drew Clearfield
    Copyrighted
    Mei Wei
    Figure 1
  • Figure 2: Effect of cooling rate on zonal pore sizes. 8-4 and 2-0.5 are cooling conditions that correspond to cooling rates in C/min applied to first and second slurries during sequential freeze casting. *** indicates statistical significance at p less than 0.005 using a Students t-test.
    Drew Clearfield
    Copyrighted
    Mei Wei
    Figure 2
  • Figure 3: Illustration of the lyophilization bonding process. Through the lyophilization of an intermediate transition zone (TZ) slurry between two anisotropic scaffolds (left), a monolithic scaffold mimicking the composition and architecture of the SZ, TZ, and CZ of articular cartilage is created,
    Drew Clearfield
    Copyrighted
    Mei Wei
    Figure 3
  • Figure 4: Microstructure of lyophilization bonded scaffold. Stitched longitudinal section of multi-zonal scaffold (left) delineating superficial (SZ), transition (TZ), calcified cartilage (CZ), and osseous (OZ) scaffold zones. Figures on right show higher magnification images of each zone
    Drew Clearfield
    Copyrighted
    Mei Wei
    Figure 4
  • Figure 5: HYA distribution in lyophilization bonded scaffold (A) and quantification of zonal FITC-HYA pixel intensity (B).
    Drew Clearfield
    Copyrighted
    Mei Wei
    Figure 5
  • Figure 6: TGA (A) and XRD (B) analyses of HA content in osseous scaffolds.
    Drew Clearfield
    Mei Wei
    Figure 6
